story:
UPDATE: WE'RE LIVE

You can buy Dojo Storm for Android in the Google Play store.

You can also buy Dojo Storm for iOS from iTunes.

BUY IT NOW BECAUSE WE WORKED REALLY HARD.



UPDATE (7/6/2015): WE MET OUR GOAL

And now, on to our stretch goals! To review, here are our active stretch goals:

  • $4000 - Classic Green Mode

  • $6000 - 80s Action Movie Side Quest 

  • $8000 - Multiplayer Support

  • $10000 - Special Edition DLC

    • The classic green mode has been unlocked! This mode is inspired by retro handheld gaming, hearkening back to the days where you kept a flashlight in the backseat of your mom's minivan so that you could game on the way home from grandma's. Here's a screenshot of what this mode will look as a finished product:

    Help us unlock the next stretch goals!

    Original Campaign Story:

    From the company that brought you Don’t Wear Your Gi to the Bar, Mastering the Crucifix, and the extended edition of The Cauliflower Chronicles comes the first ever Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu video game.

    ...click here to watch a video of the title screen (it's even more awesome with music).

    Super Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Dojo Storm: Championship Edition celebrates the grand inside joke of being a jiu-jiteiro with a tongue-in-cheek exploration of the weird and wonderful side of jiu-jitsu culture. Instead of trying to replicate the experience of training, Dojo Storm uses RPG-style mechanics to thrust players into a world where everyone takes training as seriously as we do—from our unhealthy acai obsessions to our hate for all things board-breaking.

    Play as Tim, an aspiring world champion, as you travel from a rural town to the big city of Bitsburgh to compete in the Polaris Team Invitiational, recruiting a zany team of martial artists to compete at your side along the way. You soon discover, however, that an outbreak of the McDojo virus threatens to infect jiu-jitsu, raising the stakes from winning a gold medal to saving the sanctity of jiu-jitsu as we know it. The future of the art rests on the shoulders of you and your hodge-podge team of fighters. Can you master the art of fighting and coaching in-time to save jiu-jitsu?

    • Projected Release Date: September 2015
    • Platforms: iOS, Android, PC 
    • Game Style: Retro handheld RPG
    • Estimated Gameplay: 15 to 20 hours
    • Crowdfunding Needs: Hardware and software necessary for a full, multi-platform release.
    • Stretch Goals: Additional game content and multiplayer support.

    Dojo Storm takes artistic and gameplay queues from retro roleplaying games. The world is built with an 8-bit inspired aesthetic, and combat is turn-based. As you travel from town to town, making your way toward the center of Bitsburgh for the Universe Championships, you take on challenge matches and recruit roaming fighters to join your team. With over 50 characters and upwards of 300 unique abilities, the make-up of your team and their fighting styles are uniquely your own. If you loved handheld RPGs in the 90s and early 2000s, the gameplay of Dojo Storm will feel heartwarmingly familiar.

       

    In Dojo Storm, you venture from a small rural town to a rich and vibrant city, with each neighborhood and route featuring a unique environmental personality, making world exploration just as rewarding as conquering your enemies. This world loosely parodies the real-life landmarks of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, breathing an additional layer of life and vibrancy into the gameplay for anyone that has visited the city. Even if you have never been to Pittsburgh, the detailed artwork and colorful NPCs will suck you into this digital martial arts playground.

       

    Styles make fights. The key to success in Dojo Storm is building a well-rounded team of fighters. While each fighter has his or her own unique characteristics and abilities, every fighter in the world of Dojo Storm comes from one of five fighting backgrounds:

    • Grapplers want to close the distance and take the fight to the ground but are weak against fighters that use weapons or unconventional attacks.
    • Strikers are fast and mobile but are not equipped to defend takedowns or weapon attacks.
    • Brawlers fight with their hearts but struggle to cope with more technical fighters.
    • Spirit types are unpredictable wild cards in the fighting world but crumble when facing off against styles that like to strike.
    • Weapon users are ready to put down fighters with more technical styles but are weak to fighters that are just as willing to go off the deep-end as they are.

       

    Dojo Storm features RPG-style turn-based combat. Though you compete as a team, your fights are character to character, making your strategy a mix between matching styles and knowing when to pull a fighter out of combat in favor of a new one. A match is won by forcing every fighter on the opposing to team tap out, but winning a fight is about much more than depleting hit points and picking the right style for the fight.

    As characters level-up, they learn new moves, and different moves can change the tide of the fight in different ways. Picking the right moves for your fighter’s gameplan is critical, and using those moves to maximize your strengths while exploiting weaknesses will give you the edge in a close fight. In addition to dealing damage, fighters in Dojo Storm can use moves that:

    • Stun: Paralyzes the fighter temporarily, making him unable to attack.
    • Wound: Causes the fighter to bleed each round, losing hit points much in the same way the poison status effect is used in other games.
    • Disorient: Confuses the fighter, causing him to sometimes attack himself or miss with his attack completely.
    • Blind: Kickboxer-movie-style blink mode, making the fighter woefully inaccurate.
    • Cripple: Slows the fighter down by inflicting a brutal and painful injury.

    To survive Dojo Storm, you have to fight smart. Training dynamic fighters and using their abilities strategically will be essential to your dream of becoming a jiu-jitsu champion and saving jiu-jitsu from the McDojo virus.

    With over 50 potential fighters to recruit to your team, there is no shortage of variety, but many fighters are not freely roaming the world waiting for the opportunity to join your quest. Instead, they need to be trained and unlocked. In Dojo Storm, most fighters will transform into new versions of themselves if they can get enough experience in combat. We call this ranking up, and you never can be sure how a fighter will change in the course of their career.

    Because Dojo Storm was inspired by classic handheld RPGs, we are optimizing the game experience for mobile devices—iOS and Android. In our mind, this will be the perfect way to pass the time as you wait for your match to be called or while you’re stuck at work dreaming of jiu-jitsu. At the same time, we want as many people as possible to experience the game, so we also have plans to make Dojo Storm available for PC, provided that we have the capital to do so.

    Dojo Storm is the result of a collaboration between Artechoke Media and Synersteel Studios and a partnership with Polaris and Scramble. We partnered with Polaris and Scramble because they are just as passionate about supporting the grassroots of jiu-jitsu as we are. Supporting Polaris and Scramble goes a long way toward supporting the future of our sport. We are incredibly grateful to be working with them.

    Polaris is Europe’s premier submission grappling and jiu-jitsu invitational, hosting unique, high-quality events to drive interest and support for competitive jiu-jitsu and the many talented men and women growing the art.

    Scramble is here to rescue jiu-jitsu from the downward spiral of poorly designed and shoddily manufactured training and casual gear. Scramble’s spirit of innovation has made it one of the top jiu-jitsu brands in the world.

    Mechanical Advantage Digital Records is run by a jiu-jitsu purple belt and produces bleeding edge music in the electronic genre. They produced all of the music in Dojo Storm.

    Artechoke Media is the brainchild of Marshal D. Carper (author The Cauliflower Chronicles and coauthor of Marcelo Garcia’s Advanced Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Techniques) and Matt Kirtley (the blogger behind Aesopian.com and the author of Mastering the Crucifix). Artechoke strives to promote the organic growth of jiu-jitsu thought, theory, and technique and to date we have served this goal primarily through instructional content.

    At the same time, we have no desire to turn into a widget factory that churns out instructionals for the sake of simply having something new to sell. We constantly challenge ourselves to contribute to our community in a meaningful way and to think creatively about how we can grow and strengthen jiu-jitsu. That thinking spawned our unique media-rich cloud instructionals, and it took us down the rabbit hole of creating Dojo Storm, the first-ever jiu-jitsu video game.

    For this project, Artechoke has formed a 50/50 partnership with Synersteel Studios, an independent video game development start-up based in Philadelphia. Lead by two brothers, Nick and Anthony Vaccaro, Synersteel is the product of a lifelong passion for the connective power of video games. Synersteel strives to leverage the potential that video games have for bringing people together, and like Artechoke, Synersteel is devoted to meaningful experiences rather than chasing the latest fad for the sake profit.

    Upon completion of Dojo Storm, Synersteel Studios plans to partner with nonprofits, helping them to use gaming as a tool for fundraising, engagement, and publicity while also pursuing internal development projects. In the interest of full disclosure, Marshal—an Artechoke co-owner—is now an advisor and contributor to Synersteel. He joined the team after being impressed with their work ethic and performance.

    We are turning to crowdfunding for three reasons:

    1. To accelerate the development process for Dojo Storm by securing the software and hardware that we need for a full release.
    2. To ensure that all users—iOS, Android, and PC—get access at the same time.
    3. To invite other members of the community, like fighters and coaches, to become a part of the game.

    By raising money upfront for the game, we can quickly hurdle the licensing and testing equipment challenges that we need to release Dojo Storm across iOS, Android, and PC. Currently, we are fully equipped to release on Android, but we do not want any players left out. At the same time, we hope that the interest in the potential of this project will lead to some of our favorite jiu-jitsu personalities becoming playable characters or parts of quest-lines.

    To be clear: This game will be finished with or without crowdfunding. With crowdfunding, everyone will have access at the same time and we can better estimate our delivery date: October 2015. Your upfront support will put wind in our sails. Without your support, we will row to the finish line and get there, eventually, but it’s difficult to say how long that would take and whether or not we will be able to release on android, iOS, and PC simultenaously. 

    Your support for Dojo Storm means the world to us, and we want to make sure that we thank you for having faith in us. If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask us. Note: some perks are limited, so get them while you can. Also, some perks are subject to terms and approval, so please read the perk description here and in the perk section for more details.

    A summary of the perks available for Dojo Storm:

    • $10 - Game Download + Special Thanks Credit + Closed Beta Invitation.

    • $25 - White Belt Problems + Game Download.

    • $30 - The Cauliflower Chronicles, Second Edition + Game Download

    • $45 - Mastering the Crucifix + Game Download 

    • $60 - Strategy Guide + Game Download

    • $350 - In-Game Character Placement 

    • $500 - Business Sponsorship 

    • $1000 - Gym Side Quest Package

    White Belt Problems

    White Belt Problems aims to be the definitive collection of frequently asked questions for anyone new to Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. From the author of Mastering the Crucifix and the author of the Cauliflower Chronicles, this book combines the collective wisdom of two long-time practitioners and addresses the full scope of concerns and inquiries that trouble the minds of uninitiated jiu-jiteiros. An end-to-end, White Belt Problems answers all of the questions you were afraid to ask, making it easier for you to join the sport and enjoy your training. A great gift for new students or to round out your own collection.

    The Cauliflower Chronicles, Second Edition

    The second edition of this hit martial arts travel memoir contains bonus author commentary and illustrations from Gawakoto's Bong Abad. When Marshal Carper broke up with his long-time girlfriend, he packed up his white belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu and moved from rural Pennsylvania to Hilo, Hawaii to train at the BJ Penn MMA Academy. The Cauliflower Chronicles follow Carper's adventures and misadventures, both on the mat and around the island. The Cauliflower Chronicles is a must-read for both sports fans and travel buffs, showing a side of mixed martial arts and Hawaii not available anywhere else.

    Mastering the Crucifix

    Aesopian.com was one of the first jiu-jitsu blogs. Its owner, Matt Kirtley, started writing about the sport as a blue belt, cataloging techniques and ideas while also sifting through mountains of training resources to glean new insights into concepts and theories. Many years later, Kirtley is now an Eduardo de Lima black belt, and his blog is still an important contributor to jiu-jitsu thought and technique. In his first book, Kirtley unveils the crucifix system that he began construction as a white belt. His approach to the crucifix and reverse omoplata fully integrates this under-used position into a well-rounded arsenal, helping you to fill a hole in your game that you may not even know existed. Learn Kirtley’s crucifix game before your training partners do.

    Dojo Storm Strategy Guide

    In a bid to recapture the nostalgia of our internet-free youth, we are designing a strategy guide in the classic format of old school strategy guides. Get all of the inside tips and tricks you need to conquer the Dojo Storm world and uncover its hidden secrets. In addition to the maps and detailed explanations of how to perfect your team, you can look behind the scenes at the making of Dojo Storm to learn more about the work that went into designing the Dojo Storm experience.

    In-Game Character Placement

    As a kid, you may have dreamed about entering the worlds of your favorite video games, becoming one of the characters that shapes the plot and the history of fictional playgrounds. Now you can live that dream. With your direction and source material, we will transform you into a Dojo Storm character, complete with a custom appearance and custom attacks. As a character in the world, every person that plays Dojo Storm will have the chance to add you to their team of fighters.

    *We reserve the right to decline your participation if we believe there is not a good fit. If this happens, you will receive a full refund.

    Business Sponsorship

    We believe in supporting the jiu-jitsu community and are always looking to collaborate with businesses as passionate about the community as we are. This is what lead to our working with Polaris and Scramble, and we would love to use Dojo Storm as a platform for supporting your business. We will feature your business on the Dojo Storm website. Your logo will appear on the splash screen. Your business will appear on in-game billboards. And if it is relevant, an in-game item will be tied to your business. For example, if you sell supplements, players could buy them in the game.

    *We reserve the right to decline your participation if we believe there is not a good fit or if your business conflicts with an existing sponsor. If this happens, you will receive a full refund. If you have any questions, please contact us directly.

    Gym Side Quest Package

    This is the ultimate tribute to your gym. Capture the unique personality of your gym and your instructor with a gym-themed Dojo Storm side quest. Players will be able to meet and recruit your instructor and three other custom characters to join their teams all while exploring a dedicated, customized game area. This perk is a one-of-a-kind opportunity to connect your gym to jiu-jitsu history. Use this perk to say thank you to your instructor or as a marketing tool to separate your gym from every other jiu-jitsu gym in the area.

    *We reserve the right to decline your participation if we believe there is not a good fit or if your business conflicts with an existing interest. If this happens, you will receive a full refund. If you have any questions, please contact us directly.

    Our minimum goal is so low, relative to the $500,000 and up goals that are usual for video game projects, because we have already invested significant personal time and resources to make this game a reality. Rather than use crowdfunding to fund our salaries, we are using funds to cover basic development expenses. Our stretch goals are simple, and they are designed with the same philosophy.

    • $4000 - Classic Green Mode

    • $6000 - 80s Action Movie Side Quest 

    • $8000 - Multiplayer Support

    • $10000 - Special Edition DLC
    Classic Gameboy Green Mode: Get the true retro mobile gaming experience with this classic mode. You won't need a portable light kit and a backpack full of AA batteries to play the game, but it will feel like the old days.
    80s Action Movie Side Quest: Take some time away from training for Polaris to take on an adventure inspired by your favorite classic action films. Explore all-new areas and recruit all-new fighters to your team along the way.
    Multiplayer Support: Take your team beyond the Polaris Team Invitational and challenge your training partners to team vs. team matches. This is a great way to pass the time before class or to game-away a long tournament day.
    Special Edition DLC: We will expand the Dojo Storm universe with more playable areas and recruitable characters. For this perk, we are setting aside $1000 to use as sponsorship money for a talented jiu-jiteiro. The DLC would be themed after this fighter, using their fighting style and personality as inspiration.

    In recent months, a slew of failed crowdfunding campaigns with grand promises and waves of hype behind them have fallen apart, leaving backers without their rewards or the games that they so desperately wanted to play. We are sensitive to these realities, and want to address the risks of this campaign head-on with clear and detailed explanations of how we are mitigating them.

    Reliability: Artechoke ran a crowdfunding campaign in February of 2014 to fund our first cloud instructional, Mastering the Crucifix. Our goal was $4000 and we raised $5711. We delivered the product and the rewards as promised. Marshal and Matt are active members of the jiu-jitsu community and have always kept their promises. This project will not be any different.

    Financial: The biggest fear in crowdfunding is that the project will fade into the ether and take your money with it. We are committed to completing this game regardless of the performance of the crowdfunding campaign. We have already invested significant personal time and money into it, and we are prepared to get the game released no matter what (but platform support may be limited).

    Another point of comfort: many video games that pursue crowdfunding incorporate employee salaries into their estimates, increasing the scope of their initial goals into the six figures and beyond. Where even small games request that backers contribute $100,000, we are only asking for $3400. Any money we raise beyond that will be invested into improving the game, not our standard of living.

    Scope: Many crowdfunded games fall into the trap of being overly ambitious. We have deliberately limited our gameplay mechanics, world-size, and art style to insulate ourselves from scope creep. Unlike some campaigns that feature mock-ups of GUIs only, Dojo Storm is currently playable with major mechanics implemented and the majority of the game art completed, so we know with certainty that we can deliver on our promises. We are not asking for your help to start development; we are asking for your help to complete development, which in our minds are two very different goals, and we hope you agree.

    Delivery Date: Though we are planning for an Oct. 2015 release, unforeseen obstacles could lead to delivery delays. Of all of the risks, this is one that we are willing to compromise on. We would rather take the time to release a polished product, and we hope that the Artechoke track record quells any worry.

    Enjoyment: We think that Dojo Storm is hilarious, but there is of course a risk that you will not agree. If you liked Don’t Wear Your Gi to the Bar or The Cauliflower Chronicles, you will almost certainly love your romp through this retro-inspired world, but we can’t promise that you have the quality of tastes that we do.
story_txt:
UPDATE: WE'RE LIVEYou can buy Dojo Storm for Android in the Google Play store.You can also buy Dojo Storm for iOS from iTunes.BUY IT NOW BECAUSE WE WORKED REALLY HARD.UPDATE (7/6/2015): WE MET OUR GOALAnd now, on to our stretch goals! To review, here are our active stretch goals:$4000 - Classic Green Mode$6000 - 80s Action Movie Side Quest $8000 - Multiplayer Support$10000 - Special Edition DLCThe classic green mode has been unlocked! This mode is inspired by retro handheld gaming, hearkening back to the days where you kept a flashlight in the backseat of your mom's minivan so that you could game on the way home from grandma's. Here's a screenshot of what this mode will look as a finished product:Help us unlock the next stretch goals!Original Campaign Story:From the company that brought you Don’t Wear Your Gi to the
Bar, Mastering the Crucifix, and the extended edition of The Cauliflower Chronicles
comes the first ever Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu video game.



...click here to watch a video of the title screen (it's even more awesome with music).
Super Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Dojo Storm: Championship Edition
celebrates the grand inside joke of being a jiu-jiteiro with a tongue-in-cheek
exploration of the weird and wonderful side of jiu-jitsu culture. Instead of
trying to replicate the experience of training, Dojo Storm uses RPG-style
mechanics to thrust players into a world where everyone takes training as
seriously as we do—from our unhealthy acai obsessions to our hate for all
things board-breaking.
Play as Tim, an aspiring world champion, as you travel from
a rural town to the big city of Bitsburgh to compete in the Polaris Team Invitiational, recruiting a zany team of
martial artists to compete at your side along the way. You soon discover,
however, that an outbreak of the McDojo virus threatens to infect jiu-jitsu,
raising the stakes from winning a gold medal to saving the sanctity of
jiu-jitsu as we know it. The future of the art rests on the shoulders of you
and your hodge-podge team of fighters. Can you master the art of fighting and
coaching in-time to save jiu-jitsu?





Projected
Release Date: September 2015


Platforms:
iOS, Android, PC 


Game
Style: Retro handheld RPG


Estimated Gameplay: 15 to 20 hours

Crowdfunding
Needs: Hardware and software necessary for a full, multi-platform release.


Stretch Goals: Additional game content and multiplayer support.



Dojo Storm takes artistic and gameplay queues from retro
roleplaying games. The world is built with an 8-bit inspired aesthetic, and
combat is turn-based. As you travel from town to town, making your way toward the
center of Bitsburgh for the Universe Championships, you take on challenge
matches and recruit roaming fighters to join your team. With over 50 characters
and upwards of 300 unique abilities, the make-up of your team and their
fighting styles are uniquely your own. If you loved handheld RPGs in the 90s
and early 2000s, the gameplay of Dojo Storm will feel heartwarmingly familiar.

   


In Dojo Storm, you venture from a small rural town to a rich
and vibrant city, with each neighborhood and route featuring a unique
environmental personality, making world exploration just as rewarding as
conquering your enemies. This world loosely parodies the real-life landmarks of
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, breathing an additional layer of life and vibrancy
into the gameplay for anyone that has visited the city. Even if you have never
been to Pittsburgh, the detailed artwork and colorful NPCs will suck you into
this digital martial arts playground.
   




Styles make fights. The key to success in Dojo Storm is
building a well-rounded team of fighters. While each fighter has his or her own
unique characteristics and abilities, every fighter in the world of Dojo Storm
comes from one of five fighting backgrounds:


Grapplers want to
close the distance and take the fight to the ground but are weak against fighters
that use weapons or unconventional attacks.


Strikers are fast and mobile but are
not equipped to defend takedowns or weapon attacks.


Brawlers fight with their hearts but
struggle to cope with more technical fighters.


Spirit types are unpredictable wild
cards in the fighting world but crumble when facing off against styles that
like to strike.


Weapon users are ready to put down
fighters with more technical styles but are weak to fighters that are just as
willing to go off the deep-end as they are.



   
Dojo Storm features RPG-style turn-based combat. Though you
compete as a team, your fights are character to character, making your strategy
a mix between matching styles and knowing when to pull a fighter out of combat
in favor of a new one. A match is won by forcing every fighter on the opposing
to team tap out, but winning a fight is about much more than depleting hit points
and picking the right style for the fight.
As characters level-up, they learn new moves, and different
moves can change the tide of the fight in different ways. Picking the right
moves for your fighter’s gameplan is critical, and using those moves to maximize
your strengths while exploiting weaknesses will give you the edge in a close
fight. In addition to dealing damage, fighters in Dojo Storm can use moves
that:


Stun: Paralyzes the fighter temporarily, making
him unable to attack.


Wound: Causes the fighter to bleed each round,
losing hit points much in the same way the poison status effect is used in
other games.


Disorient: Confuses the fighter, causing him to
sometimes attack himself or miss with his attack completely.


Blind: Kickboxer-movie-style blink mode, making
the fighter woefully inaccurate.


Cripple: Slows the fighter down by inflicting a
brutal and painful injury.


To survive Dojo Storm, you have to fight smart. Training
dynamic fighters and using their abilities strategically will be essential to
your dream of becoming a jiu-jitsu champion and saving jiu-jitsu from the McDojo virus.

With over 50 potential fighters to recruit to your team,
there is no shortage of variety, but many fighters are not freely roaming the
world waiting for the opportunity to join your quest. Instead, they need to be
trained and unlocked. In Dojo Storm, most fighters will transform into new
versions of themselves if they can get enough experience in combat. We call
this ranking up, and you never can be sure how a fighter will change in the
course of their career.

Because Dojo Storm was inspired by classic handheld RPGs, we
are optimizing the game experience for mobile devices—iOS and Android. In our
mind, this will be the perfect way to pass the time as you wait for your match
to be called or while you’re stuck at work dreaming of jiu-jitsu. At the same
time, we want as many people as possible to experience the game, so we also
have plans to make Dojo Storm available for PC, provided that we have the capital
to do so.

Dojo Storm is the result of a collaboration between Artechoke
Media and Synersteel Studios and a partnership with Polaris and Scramble. We partnered with Polaris and Scramble because they are just as passionate about supporting the grassroots of jiu-jitsu as we are. Supporting Polaris and Scramble goes a long way toward supporting the future of our sport. We are incredibly grateful to be working with them.
Polaris is Europe’s
premier submission grappling and jiu-jitsu invitational, hosting unique,
high-quality events to drive interest and support for competitive jiu-jitsu and
the many talented men and women growing the art.
Scramble is here to
rescue jiu-jitsu from the downward spiral of poorly designed and shoddily
manufactured training and casual gear. Scramble’s spirit of innovation has made
it one of the top jiu-jitsu brands in the world.Mechanical Advantage Digital Records is run by a jiu-jitsu purple belt and produces bleeding edge music in the electronic genre. They produced all of the music in Dojo Storm.

Artechoke Media is the brainchild of Marshal D. Carper
(author The Cauliflower Chronicles and coauthor of Marcelo Garcia’s Advanced
Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Techniques) and Matt Kirtley (the blogger behind
Aesopian.com and the author of Mastering the Crucifix). Artechoke strives to
promote the organic growth of jiu-jitsu thought, theory, and technique and to
date we have served this goal primarily through instructional content. 
At the same time, we have no desire to turn into a widget
factory that churns out instructionals for the sake of simply having something
new to sell. We constantly challenge ourselves to contribute to our community
in a meaningful way and to think creatively about how we can grow and
strengthen jiu-jitsu. That thinking spawned our unique media-rich cloud
instructionals, and it took us down the rabbit hole of creating Dojo Storm, the
first-ever jiu-jitsu video game.

For this project, Artechoke has formed a 50/50 partnership
with Synersteel Studios, an independent video game development start-up based
in Philadelphia. Lead by two brothers, Nick and Anthony Vaccaro, Synersteel is
the product of a lifelong passion for the connective power of video games.
Synersteel strives to leverage the potential that video games have for bringing
people together, and like Artechoke, Synersteel is devoted to meaningful experiences
rather than chasing the latest fad for the sake profit.
Upon completion of Dojo Storm, Synersteel Studios plans to
partner with nonprofits, helping them to use gaming as a tool for fundraising,
engagement, and publicity while also pursuing internal development projects. In
the interest of full disclosure, Marshal—an Artechoke co-owner—is now an
advisor and contributor to Synersteel. He joined the team after being impressed
with their work ethic and performance.

We are turning to crowdfunding for three reasons:


To accelerate the development process for Dojo Storm by
securing the software and hardware that we need for a full release.


To ensure that all users—iOS, Android, and PC—get access
at the same time.


To invite other members of the community, like fighters
and coaches, to become a part of the game.


By raising money upfront for the game, we can quickly hurdle
the licensing and testing equipment challenges that we need to release Dojo
Storm across iOS, Android, and PC. Currently, we are fully equipped to release
on Android, but we do not want any players left out. At the same time, we hope
that the interest in the potential of this project will lead to some of our
favorite jiu-jitsu personalities becoming playable characters or parts of
quest-lines.
To be clear: This game will be finished with or without
crowdfunding. With crowdfunding, everyone will have access at the same time and
we can better estimate our delivery date: October 2015. Your upfront support
will put wind in our sails. Without your support, we will row to the finish line
and get there, eventually, but it’s difficult to say how long that would take and whether or not we will be able to release on android, iOS, and PC simultenaously. 
Your support for Dojo Storm means the world to us, and we want to make sure that we thank you for having faith in us. If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask us. Note: some perks are limited, so get them while you can. Also, some perks are subject to terms and approval, so please read the perk description here and in the perk section for more details.A summary of the perks available for Dojo Storm:
$10 - Game Download + Special Thanks Credit + Closed Beta Invitation.
$25 - White Belt Problems + Game Download.
$30 - The Cauliflower Chronicles, Second Edition + Game Download
$45 - Mastering the Crucifix + Game Download 
$60 - Strategy Guide + Game Download
$350 - In-Game Character Placement 
$500 - Business Sponsorship 
$1000 - Gym Side Quest Package
White Belt Problems

White Belt Problems aims to be the definitive collection of frequently asked questions for anyone new to Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. From the author of Mastering the Crucifix and the author of the Cauliflower Chronicles, this book combines the collective wisdom of two long-time practitioners and addresses the full scope of concerns and inquiries that trouble the minds of uninitiated jiu-jiteiros. An end-to-end, White Belt Problems answers all of the questions you were afraid to ask, making it easier for you to join the sport and enjoy your training. A great gift for new students or to round out your own collection.
The Cauliflower Chronicles, Second Edition

The second edition of this hit martial arts travel memoir contains bonus author commentary and illustrations from Gawakoto's Bong Abad. When Marshal Carper broke up with his long-time girlfriend, he packed up his white belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu and moved from rural Pennsylvania to Hilo, Hawaii to train at the BJ Penn MMA Academy. The Cauliflower Chronicles follow Carper's adventures and misadventures, both on the mat and around the island. The Cauliflower Chronicles is a must-read for both sports fans and travel buffs, showing a side of mixed martial arts and Hawaii not available anywhere else.
Mastering the Crucifix

Aesopian.com was one of the first jiu-jitsu blogs. Its owner, Matt Kirtley, started writing about the sport as a blue belt, cataloging techniques and ideas while also sifting through mountains of training resources to glean new insights into concepts and theories. Many years later, Kirtley is now an Eduardo de Lima black belt, and his blog is still an important contributor to jiu-jitsu thought and technique. In his first book, Kirtley unveils the crucifix system that he began construction as a white belt. His approach to the crucifix and reverse omoplata fully integrates this under-used position into a well-rounded arsenal, helping you to fill a hole in your game that you may not even know existed. Learn Kirtley’s crucifix game before your training partners do.
Dojo Storm Strategy Guide
In a bid to recapture the nostalgia of our internet-free youth, we are designing a strategy guide in the classic format of old school strategy guides. Get all of the inside tips and tricks you need to conquer the Dojo Storm world and uncover its hidden secrets. In addition to the maps and detailed explanations of how to perfect your team, you can look behind the scenes at the making of Dojo Storm to learn more about the work that went into designing the Dojo Storm experience.
In-Game Character Placement
As a kid, you may have dreamed about entering the worlds of your favorite video games, becoming one of the characters that shapes the plot and the history of fictional playgrounds. Now you can live that dream. With your direction and source material, we will transform you into a Dojo Storm character, complete with a custom appearance and custom attacks. As a character in the world, every person that plays Dojo Storm will have the chance to add you to their team of fighters.
*We reserve the right to decline your participation if we believe there is not a good fit. If this happens, you will receive a full refund.
Business Sponsorship
We believe in supporting the jiu-jitsu community and are always looking to collaborate with businesses as passionate about the community as we are. This is what lead to our working with Polaris and Scramble, and we would love to use Dojo Storm as a platform for supporting your business. We will feature your business on the Dojo Storm website. Your logo will appear on the splash screen. Your business will appear on in-game billboards. And if it is relevant, an in-game item will be tied to your business. For example, if you sell supplements, players could buy them in the game.
*We reserve the right to decline your participation if we believe there is not a good fit or if your business conflicts with an existing sponsor. If this happens, you will receive a full refund. If you have any questions, please contact us directly.
Gym Side Quest Package
This is the ultimate tribute to your gym. Capture the unique personality of your gym and your instructor with a gym-themed Dojo Storm side quest. Players will be able to meet and recruit your instructor and three other custom characters to join their teams all while exploring a dedicated, customized game area. This perk is a one-of-a-kind opportunity to connect your gym to jiu-jitsu history. Use this perk to say thank you to your instructor or as a marketing tool to separate your gym from every other jiu-jitsu gym in the area.
*We reserve the right to decline your participation if we believe there is not a good fit or if your business conflicts with an existing interest. If this happens, you will receive a full refund. If you have any questions, please contact us directly.


Our minimum goal is so low, relative to the $500,000 and up goals that are usual for video game projects, because we have already invested significant personal time and resources to make this game a reality. Rather than use crowdfunding to fund our salaries, we are using funds to cover basic development expenses. Our stretch goals are simple, and they are designed with the same philosophy.


$4000 - Classic Green Mode
$6000 - 80s Action Movie Side Quest 
$8000 - Multiplayer Support
$10000 - Special Edition DLC


Classic Gameboy Green Mode: Get the true retro mobile gaming experience with this classic mode. You won't need a portable light kit and a backpack full of AA batteries to play the game, but it will feel like the old days.

80s Action Movie Side Quest: Take some time away from training for Polaris to take on an adventure inspired by your favorite classic action films. Explore all-new areas and recruit all-new fighters to your team along the way.

Multiplayer Support: Take your team beyond the Polaris Team Invitational and challenge your training partners to team vs. team matches. This is a great way to pass the time before class or to game-away a long tournament day.

Special Edition DLC: We will expand the Dojo Storm universe with more playable areas and recruitable characters. For this perk, we are setting aside $1000 to use as sponsorship money for a talented jiu-jiteiro. The DLC would be themed after this fighter, using their fighting style and personality as inspiration.



In recent months, a slew of failed crowdfunding campaigns
with grand promises and waves of hype behind them have fallen apart, leaving
backers without their rewards or the games that they so desperately wanted to
play. We are sensitive to these realities, and want to address the risks of
this campaign head-on with clear and detailed explanations of how we are
mitigating them.
Reliability:
Artechoke ran a crowdfunding campaign in February of 2014 to fund our first

$5711. We delivered the product and the rewards as promised. Marshal and Matt
are active members of the jiu-jitsu community and have always kept their

Financial:
The biggest fear in crowdfunding is that the project will fade into the ether

invested significant personal time and money into it, and we are prepared to

Another point of comfort: many video games that pursue crowdfunding incorporate employee salaries into their estimates, increasing the scope of their initial goals into the six figures and beyond. Where even small games request that backers contribute $100,000, we are only asking for $3400. Any money we raise beyond that will be invested into improving the game, not our standard of living.

crowdfunded games fall into the trap of being overly ambitious. We have

Delivery
Date: Though we are planning for an Oct. 2015 release, unforeseen obstacles
could lead to delivery delays. Of all of the risks, this is one that we are

We think that Dojo Storm is hilarious, but there is of course a risk that
you will not agree. If you liked Don’t Wear Your Gi to the Bar or The
Cauliflower Chronicles, you will almost certainly love your romp through this
retro-inspired world, but we can’t promise that you have the quality of tastes that we
do.

story:
NOW TAKING FINAL PRE-ORDERS FOR LAST REMAINING COPIES OF THIS STRICTLY LIMITED COLLECTOR'S SET!

Add foil packs, sealed boxes, the custom binder, or more "Hidden Vault" boxes to your order during checkout.

Packs of FALLOUT ® "Series 2" are already available now, and as part of the "Hidden Vault" Collector's Box!

You can add more packs, or whole boxes to your order at checkout.
story_txt: NOW TAKING FINAL PRE-ORDERS FOR LAST REMAINING COPIES OF THIS STRICTLY LIMITED COLLECTOR'S SET!Add foil packs, sealed boxes, the custom binder, or more "Hidden Vault" boxes to your order during checkout.Packs of FALLOUT ® "Series 2" are already available now, and as part of the "Hidden Vault" Collector's Box!You can add more packs, or whole boxes to your order at checkout.

story:
Final Rush is nearly complete, smooth playing, fast paced first person shooter for the PC, which puts the players in to the role of military special force peacekeepers on a futuristic, Earth-like planet.

Up to four players fight against hundreds and thousands of attackers, which come in huge, wave based assaults - and culminates in a massive boss battle!

If you distill Final Rush down into a simple formula, this is what you'll get:

Stay Alive - > Destroy enemies - > Get points - > Spend Points on upgrades and better weapons - > Destroy more enemies - > and see if you can make it to the end and overcome the boss!

Easier said than done, and more fun done than said.

"So why pledge? It sounds like Final Rush is pretty much done." - Some guy

Final Rush is almost done; but we're looking to improve the bad parts and expand the good parts of the game. Most big studios spend more in one day than the entire budget of Final Rush. We want to continue imrpoving the game while we wait to get it up on Steam's Greenlight, and get the game out to gamers.

The initial goal of the Indiegogo is to get enough funds to overhaul and improve the gameplay experience in a few areas.

These areas are as follows:

Gameplay tweaks. We want to do a collection of smaller tweaks to improve the feel of the game, and make it much more enjoyable and immersive; tweaking things like weapon reloads and melee attacks, to how the robot AI behaves.

A massively improved main menu. The current main menu is one of the oldest elements of Final Rush, and is outdated and ineffective. We want to give you a friendly, common-sense, easy to use, mouse friendly main menu, which allows you to easily interact and setup games with your friends.

Improved ingame instruction. Startup Final Rush, launch a game, and it might be a little bit confusing for first time players. We want to implement a system that guides first time players, and gets out of the way completely once you don't need it any more. There are all kinds of great tips, like sprinting while you reload your shotgun, or moving explosive barrels to better positions, which simply aren't obvious, especially to first time players, but really help make the game more fun.

In short, the goals are to take Final Rush from a game that's fun to play, to a game that's really fun to play, and easy to get into.

And that's not even touching the possibility of stretch goals, should we (hopefully) get that far.

[Note: Final Rush is currently only supported on the PC. While Mac support is on the agenda, it's not something that we can commit to until we get a little further along. We can't in good concious ask for pledges from Mac gamers without mentioning this... but if you do pledge, we'll honor your rewards as soon as the game is availible on Mac.]

"So what is Final Rush supposed to be? What is it really?" - Some Guy

Final Rush is a first person, action/sci-fi shooter being made by Strike Games, and has been in development for over two and a half years. As you can see from the trailer, it's nearly complete.

The goal of Final Rush is to provide players with a fun and highly replayable game, which can be played alone, or cooperatively with their friends (current game modes support up to 3). Eventually, we would like to support a variety of game modes, level themes, and options.

For now, the game has one game mode: Rush. The rush game mode dynamically adjusts the difficulty and rewards depending on the performance of the players. The more you play, the more rewards you get, but the harder enemies become. Rewards vary from special weapon and grenade enhancements, to the powerful, room clearing high powered ammunition.

Final Rush is also what we call a 'continual development project', which means that we're going to keep working on it, long after the game is released, and for as long as there is community interest in the game. What this means for you is a game that keeps getting bigger and better! We're going to keep giving you free content additions for the game which expand and improve every aspect of the game.

We want to make a game that has the content and quality of a AAA game; it might take us a while to get there, but we'll keep working on it.

Final Rush is built with advanced technology; starting on the Unreal Developer Kit, Final Rush eventually transitioned to a full licensed version of the Unreal® 3 Engine; the same game engine that brought you Borderlands, Mass Effect and BioShock. Moving forward, we'll be able to leverage the full power of the Unreal Engine to bring you a spectacular experience.

"What is all this about ingame rewards, why not real life loot?" - Some Guy

To be honest, there are two reasons all of our rewards (except for the super big ones) are ingame content.

The first reason is, Final Rush doesn't have much of a community yet. Posters, T-Shirts, and Mouse Pads are coo; but we think that giving players special, very limited edition -ingame- content would be better. If you like a game enough to give us support, then you should have actual game related content to play with; rather than a poster you might not like, a T-Shirt that isn't your style, or a mousepad that isn't as good as the one you have now.

The second reason is; we're lazy bastards. We'd rather spend more time working on the game and making it better than spending time, effort, and money sending you loot.

Leave us a comment if you want to have real word loot; like the content in the game, we're open to community input.

The future of Final Rush is as bright as the community interest in the game. If people like the game, then we'll continue to grow and improve the game for years to come. Whatever the case may be, the response will be equal to the interest. Less interest from the community means less work on Final Rush; but more community response (including a small but intense community) will mean big things for Final Rush.

What kind of things can you expect? More refined gameplay, more efficient graphics and code, allowing better graphics. More weapons, more levels, more enemies, and more game modes. Even a fully-fledged episodic (but integrated into one game) single player story is on the table.

If you don't want to pledge, or don't like what the game offers, that's fine - but check back in a few months and see what you think of the game.

The more people get interested in Final Rush, the more the game will grow. The more contributers, the better the game will ultimately be by release.

The biggest way you can help us is by voting for us on Steam Greenlight.

Beyond that, you can mention or follow us on Facebook and Twitter. Any positive mention is almost as good as money, so we appreciate any help.

 

We'd also like to thank you for taking the time to look at and hopefully support our project!

*special thanks to Klaypex for their music in our trailer.

We want to implement a system that guides first time players, and gets out of the way completely once you don't need it any more. There are all kinds of great tips, like sprinting while you reload your shotgun, or moving explosive barrels to better positions, which simply aren't obvious, especially to first time players, but really help make the game more fun.
In short, the goals are to take Final Rush from a game that's fun to play, to a game that's really fun to play, and easy to get into.
And that's not even touching the possibility of stretch goals, should we (hopefully) get that far.
[Note: Final Rush is currently only supported on the PC. While Mac support is on the agenda, it's not something that we can commit to until we get a little further along. We can't in good concious ask for pledges from Mac gamers without mentioning this... but if you do pledge, we'll honor your rewards as soon as the game is availible on Mac.]

"So what is Final Rush supposed to be? What is it really?" - Some Guy
Final Rush is a first person, action/sci-fi shooter being made by Strike Games, and has been in development for over two and a half years. As you can see from the trailer, it's nearly complete.
The goal of Final Rush is to provide players with a fun and highly replayable game, which can be played alone, or cooperatively with their friends (current game modes support up to 3). Eventually, we would like to support a variety of game modes, level themes, and options.
For now, the game has one game mode: Rush. The rush game mode dynamically adjusts the difficulty and rewards depending on the performance of the players. The more you play, the more rewards you get, but the harder enemies become. Rewards vary from special weapon and grenade enhancements, to the powerful, room clearing high powered ammunition.
Final Rush is also what we call a 'continual development project', which means that we're going to keep working on it, long after the game is released, and for as long as there is community interest in the game. What this means for you is a game that keeps getting bigger and better! We're going to keep giving you free content additions for the game which expand and improve every aspect of the game.
We want to make a game that has the content and quality of a AAA game; it might take us a while to get there, but we'll keep working on it.
Final Rush is built with advanced technology; starting on the Unreal Developer Kit, Final Rush eventually transitioned to a full licensed version of the Unreal® 3 Engine; the same game engine that brought you Borderlands, Mass Effect and BioShock. Moving forward, we'll be able to leverage the full power of the Unreal Engine to bring you a spectacular experience.



"What is all this about ingame rewards, why not real life loot?" - Some Guy
To be honest, there are two reasons all of our rewards (except for the super big ones) are ingame content.
The first reason is, Final Rush doesn't have much of a community yet. Posters, T-Shirts, and Mouse Pads are coo; but we think that giving players special, very limited edition -ingame- content would be better. If you like a game enough to give us support, then you should have actual game related content to play with; rather than a poster you might not like, a T-Shirt that isn't your style, or a mousepad that isn't as good as the one you have now.
The second reason is; we're lazy bastards. We'd rather spend more time working on the game and making it better than spending time, effort, and money sending you loot.
Leave us a comment if you want to have real word loot; like the content in the game, we're open to community input.

The future of Final Rush is as bright as the community interest in the game. If people like the game, then we'll continue to grow and improve the game for years to come. Whatever the case may be, the response will be equal to the interest. Less interest from the community means less work on Final Rush; but more community response (including a small but intense community) will mean big things for Final Rush.
What kind of things can you expect? More refined gameplay, more efficient graphics and code, allowing better graphics. More weapons, more levels, more enemies, and more game modes. Even a fully-fledged episodic (but integrated into one game) single player story is on the table.
If you don't want to pledge, or don't like what the game offers, that's fine - but check back in a few months and see what you think of the game.



The more people get interested in Final Rush, the more the game will grow. The more contributers, the better the game will ultimately be by release.
The biggest way you can help us is by voting for us on Steam Greenlight.
Beyond that, you can mention or follow us on Facebook and Twitter. Any positive mention is almost as good as money, so we appreciate any help.
 
We'd also like to thank you for taking the time to look at and hopefully support our project!
*special thanks to Klaypex for their music in our trailer.

story:
Tulpa is a game vacillating between weird puzzles and symbolic narrative, both seen through the prism of surreal artwork and atmospheric music.

Tulpa is a puzzle-platformer game, in which the player controls two characters, a girl named Ophelia and a boy named Oliver, that travel through an ever-changing world.

The characters possess different abilities and perceive the world differently. This makes the survival of both characters non-trivial, as traversing the world and overcoming its challenges demands that the player has both perspectives in mind.

Story-wise the game revolves around concepts borrowed from occultism and theosophy, with thought forms (or “Tulpae”) on the focal point. Characters hide twisted secrets and the world transforms to pair with their psychology.

Symbolism is also used along those lines with both game objects and -literal- symbols (we call them “Glyphs”), filling the world, giving information to the player about the story as well as about the challenge he is facing.

With all these in-place, it comes down to the player to find out the grim past of our (anti-?)heroine and her tulpa.

Basic Controls

The game’s controls regarding character movement follow the well-known and established control patterns of the platformer genre.
Player uses the arrow keys for moving Ophelia to the left or to the right and space for jumping and climbing.
When you switch over to Oliver, the arrow keys are used to set him in motion in both the horizontal and vertical axes, floating near his beloved Ophelia.

Character Abilities

Ophelia doesn’t have any special ability. Her role is interacting with the material world by means of pushing and grabbing stuff around.
Oliver’s ability on the other hand is the interaction with otherworldly objects using a telekinetic power, directed by the player using his mouse.

Sanity

Oliver is Ophelia’s tulpa. He was created by her own mind in need for support.
That cause has an effect. Ophelia needs Oliver to be close, otherwise she begins to lose her sanity, ensuing an inevitable death.

The aesthetics are focused on flat colored models and fine tuned full-screen effects for the generation of minimalistic but intense and smooth-looking scenes.

The graphical concepts are heavily inspired by the works of Salvador Dali, Jacek Yerka as well as other known (and unknown) artists.

On the gaming side, great influences were Yume Nikki, Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet, American McGee's Alice and Limbo.

Finally, the Glyphs being a major characteristic of the game aesthetics, follow a sketched/scribbled style adding obscurity on the -already twisted- matters presented.

Tulpa is dark, it's eerie. The same goes for Red Aura’s music.

We knew it from the very first hearing, Red Aura was the missing puzzle piece of this game. We share very much the same theme and mood. Paradoxical!

Red Aura’s experimental and dark ambient elements make Tulpa shine… darker.



As for the sound effects, if we manage to reach our goal, Luke Thomas is going to work on it to give the game that final touch it needs to feel smooth and complete.

From development perspective, a huge amount of work is already done for Tulpa.

So you may ask why we need your help?
For our game to be released we need to optimize both some pieces of code and part of the assets (mostly audio).
Apparently that needs tools we can’t afford while we are still students (with no full-time jobs).

That means that we need two Unity Pro licenses, sound effects and to get our musician a new laptop, since her last one doesn't work.

So if you like the game and want to play it you can help us by contributing any amount you want towards our goal.

Potential risks

Only one potential risk exists: it is kind of macabre and involves one or more members of the team. So Tulpa will definitely be released sooner or later.

However, since polishing may take several months to complete, in the meantime we will keep you up-to-date with the latest development news and (why not) invite you over to beta-test the hell out of our game (assuming you agree to be heavily spoiled story-wise).

On the right side of this page you will find the levels of funding you can contribute.

Under the title of each perk you can see information about your rewards, our tokens of gratitude for your help.

In case your perk includes a poster or a canvas print, you can pick any scene out of the following.

Controller/GamePad Support (5000$)

Tulpa was designed with the keyboard-mouse control scheme in mind, so it needs some refactoring to properly support gamepads. Achieving this stretch goal will allow us work on this feature.

Console Port (10000$)

Our second stretch goal is adapting Tulpa for release on Xbox One through ID@Xbox (the Xbox independent developer publishing program).

Sequel / Spin-off (15000$)

Your support was basically enough to provide funds to make another game.
Given enough time, we can plan out a Tulpa sequel or spin-off, to add more depth and detail to the story and the characters.



Thanks in advance!

Thanks for taking the time to check our campaign!

Any kind of support is really appreciated, so you can contribute to the project just by sharing this campaign with your friends, since we really need exposure to make it!
Comments and feedback of all kinds will be really helpful too!

Tulpa is also on Steam Greenlight, so please vote for us, it will be much appreciated.

You can also find us on our website and on our Facebook and Twitter pages, or contact us via e-mail on contact@tulpagame.com.

story:
Πατήστε εδώ για περιγραφή στα Ελληνικά

Tinyplanet, a series of educational games to teach kids colors, shapes, numbers, letters and more through fun puzzle games. IN GREEK!

Update1: You can play 3 demo games

 

What is Tinyplanet?


There are many educational games that are made for preschoolers. Games that can be played on an internet browser, games that you can buy or download to your PC, apps for iphone, Android, etc. But when we searched for such games in languages other than English, particularly in Greek, we could not find many. In the past, Greek was one of the major languages of the world. That is why we started making a series of games in our own language, Greek. One of the reasons we put the Tinyplanet project in Indiegogo is that it can be extended to other languages if there is interest from supporters.

 

Why Tinyplanet?

As parents of toddlers, we quickly realized that the children already know how to use the mouse and the computer even before we show them how. The major deficiencies of the games we found as a result of our search are related to language and the teaching methods used (if used at all). Few applications are written for children who speak Greek, either as mother language, or as a foreign language. Also most games are designed to keep children busy and distract them like a babysitter. In fact, apart from using the computer, the application may use many teaching tools that will make the child develop interest in learning, for example colors, shapes, letters, numbers etc. So we decided to create this series of games through which children can learn by playing games based on a choice of exciting topics.

  

The Games

Tinyplanet is a series of games designed to help toddlers come in contact with basic knowledge of preschoolers. We use a nearly consistent set of games for each subject so the child is focused on understanding the topic and not the way the game is played. The groups of games that we are preparing or have built are:

  • card Game - The topic is presented in a series of cards. The child has to choose the right topic every time,
  • the Memory Game - A favorite for many children, The Memory Game helps reinforce the topics, while also developing a child's memory,
  • matching - This is an extension of The Memory Game except that instead of having all the cards hidden and matching identical cards, the children will match related cards. For example matching the color red with a red car,
  • puzzle - This game allows children to put together puzzles related to the topics provided,
  • complete the Pattern - This game challenges children to complete a pattern of cards from a set of available cards.

Many more games could be added after hearing your suggestions.

 

The Topics

Each topic will be presented from a game series like the one we described above. The topics currently planned are:

  • colors,
  • shapes,
  • numbers,
  • letters,
  • animals.

Many more games could be added after hearing your suggestions.

 

Current Progress

We currently have built a "game machine" for the card games and the memory games. Games "Complete the Pattern" and "Matching" are under development and will soon be ready for testing. The graphics of the game are originals and designed exclusively for the Tinyplanet series. We have already made some graphics for cards that can be used for several of the topics.

 

Getting to a Live Product

Our plan is that the final product will consist of a series of games designed in Flash. Everyone will be able play them for free at Tinyplanet.gr. In order to release tinyplanet we have to:

  • finish the two types of games that have not been finished,
  • build the puzzle game,
  • design graphics for most of the topics,
  • enrich the graphics that have been made to test the "game engine",
  • record sound (voice) for the games,
  • find music that fits with the concept of the game,
  • build the site Tinyplanet.gr to present games.

With the necessary funding we plan to publish the site with the first games in Μarch 2013.

 

Expansion ideas

Tinyplanet is a series of games. Some of them could be transferred to iphone, ipad or android. With additional funding we could translate Tinyplanet in other languages that lack preschool games. To implement such an expansion we need help from friends who speak these languages and can provide us with the corresponding material (voice and text).

 

Help us spread the word

If you want to see this project happening, you can help us find our funders:
-promote this campaign on Facebook or Twitter (like and tweet buttons found under the Video)
-like our Facebook page - www.facebook.com/tinyplanetgr
-follow us on Twitter - @tinyplanetgr
-post on your personal (or friend's) blog
-e-mail it or embed it on your site (code found under the Video)
-spread the word to Friends and Family :)

story:
Do you have an insane passion for pasta, pizza, risotto, prosciutto, wine and other wonderful inventions like these? That's the tiny Italian soul in you! Why not listen to it some more and support the Italian quidditch National Team, then?


Quidditch in Italy

We represent a nation that, despite its still not incredible density in terms of teams and players, is doing its best to be one of the leading forces in European quidditch. With the only team coming from a country that wasn't the hosting one for the first edition of European regionals, we always looked for internationality, and the Global Games are for us a chance to show that us not being there from as early as other countries is not stopping us from having a steady growth, and that we deserve any attention we can get on the international stage.

The first italian team registered with the IQA was Milano Meneghins Quidditch in 2012, and we are now up to 5 official teams with Lunatica Quidditch Club from Brindisi being the team that reached the 4th place during the most recent European regional championship, despite having only 8 players in their roster. We have come a long way and we still have an even longer way to go, and we want to show you what we've accomplished so far and how Italian quidditch is developing its own distinctive traits.


The national team



The Azzurri side (from "azzurro", light blue, the color that italian sides of all sports usually wear) was announced in Italy a few months ago, composed of players from the most active groups, and a minority from newly founded, or yet to be founded, teams. There has been a first practice in the north in March and one in the south in April, with two more scheduled before Global Games.
The roster is surprisingly diverse, considering the relatively small pool of national players, and you will soon have a chance to meet them on this campaign, and with an article in English that is being edited as I write this.


Here is why you should help us!

Helping us get to Global Games, not only you make sure that we can bring some more people than the current group that would be able to travel to Canada - right now a rather limited bunch of players - but you would also make sure that we can bring that experience back, increasing the level in our league, and in Europe, and subsequently anywhere else we get a chance to play. At the same time you will be able to experience different ways to look at the sport you love so much, and to make valuable friends in a country different from yours. Do I need to mention (again) we almost undisputedly have the best food, and wines, and art, and history, etc., and that you are welcome to visit us any time?


What you get

First, you get us! And we are adorable. Don't misunderstand, we're here to kick some ass or give it our best shot at least, but we strongly believe in the community aspect of quidditch, and you'll love having us at Global Games to hang out with, even those of us that are not so skilled in English.
Also, our perks, to be released soon, will be that touch of Italian class you were missing from your quidditch collection!


Where does your money go?

That's easily said: we estimate that to bring the entire team to Canada would cost easily over 10,000€, so if we are able to meet our goal every cent will go into getting us there.
As a non-profit sports association, we are required to reinvest any budget left by the end of the social year into activities related to the goals of our organization, so in the unfortunate case that it becomes impossible for us to be present in Vancouver, all the money raised will go into helping Italian and possibly European teams with equipment, lowering tournament fees, and helping with expenses (travelling, volunteers, etc.) that slow down the expansion of quidditch.


In Italiano! (for the folks at home)

Dal momento che questo è uno sport più diffuso all'estero che in Italia, la scelta è stata di una campagna in lingua inglese. Tuttavia vogliamo avere un occhio di riguardo per i nostri connazionali!
VI invitiamo, per mettervi in contatto con noi, a visitare il sito, la pagina Facebook, o il nostro account Twitter, che trovate su questa campagna, oppure a scriverci a info@italiaquidditch.com se volete saperne di più.
Vi saremo immensamente grati se voleste aiutarci, anche solo mandando questo link ai vostri amici. Se 100 di voi visitassero questa pagina e ognuno di questi convincesse 10 amici a donare un solo euro, avremmo soldi sufficienti a pagare un biglietto ad un giocatore della nazionale! Aiutateci a mostrare che l'Italia è una nazione da non sottovalutare :)
